comment_data.body:
would this fit in 'jumpoptions'? 

else, please look at existing options to find a more conventional name than 'cursormvonyank'
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1861,6 +1861,13 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	"line" and "screenline" cannot be used together.
 
 
+			*'cursormvonyank'* *'cmoy'* *'nocursormvonyank'* *'nocmoy'*
+'cursormvonyank' 'cmoy'	boolean	(default on)

comment_data.body: I've wanted this before but for all operations as described on the linked issue #12374 . Having one option that only applies to yank might not be worth it, and better implemented on the user config.

comment_data.body:
> [A plugin could certainly solve this](https://github.com/svban/YankAssassin.vim), but it was my understanding that people wanted it as an option.

if the plugin works well, then we probably want to avoid a new option. 
if the plugin looks small enough that we could paste some form of it in the docs.
if the plugin has annoying problems that can't be fixed without a new option or event, then we can consider a new option/event.

comment_regular_data.body: Enabling this option is going to break existing plugins, correct? In my opinion if we want to add options for changing behavior like this, we need to figure out some way of doing it without breaking plugins.

I would love to see preserved cursor position after exiting op-pending mode, not just for yank operation as @muniter said. Talking from experience, I added an option ([`config.sticky`](https://github.com/numToStr/Comment.nvim#configuration-optional) enabled by default) in `Comment.nvim` to specifically solve this issue which works flawlessly but it's useless when it comes to `.` repeat. That being said, I'll always prefer a native option over rolling my own and if dot-repeat situation can also be solved by this, then I won't mind breaking my plugin.

I also think that we can prevent breaking plugin by making the current behavior default and let user to change it as they desire.

Yes, but now plugins have to handle this option or else they will break if the user enables it. So you need a big warning in the documentation that this can break everything, and if it does indeed break one of your plugins then you can't use it. And because vim script plugins would be most likely to be affected *and* this is a change in just neovim, you don't even know if plugin maintainers are going to care about it. The good news is that I checked plugins like vim-surround and vim-exchange, and they all seem to use `y` on a visual selection.

What I had in mind is some separation between scripts and interactive use, so this wouldn't change the behavior of scripts.

I am not sure how major the breakage would be though, maybe it depends plugin to plugin, but I am pretty sure lua plugin author wouldn't mind for this option to land in core as it really enhances the op-pending mode experience. Although, I also agree that vimscript author might not care too much if changes are required inside the plugin.

title: feat: new option to prevent cursor from moving after yank
